segments.en: Numbered Discourses 8
1. Love
10. Trash

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā campāyaṃ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
segments.en: Now at that time the mendicants accused a mendicant of an offense.

segments.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno aññenāññaṃ paṭicarati, bahiddhā kathaṃ apanāmeti, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
segments.en: The accused mendicant dodged the issue, distracted the discussion with irrelevant points, and displayed annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
“Mendicants, throw this person out!
Throw this person out!
This person should be shown the door.
Why should you be vexed by an outsider?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekaccassa puggalassa tādisaṃyeva hoti abhikkantaṃ paṭikkantaṃ ālokitaṃ vilokitaṃ samiñjitaṃ pasāritaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇaṃ, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ—
segments.en: Take a case where a certain person looks just the same as other good-natured mendicants when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and aside, when bending and extending the limbs, and when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes.
That is, so long as the mendicants don’t notice his offense.

segments.pli: Yato ca khvassa bhikkhū āpattiṃ passanti, tamenaṃ evaṃ jānanti:
segments.en: But when the mendicants notice the offense, they know that he’s
a corrupt ascetic, just useless trash.
When they realize this they send him away.
Why is that?
So that he doesn’t corrupt good-natured mendicants.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, sampanne yavakaraṇe yavadūsī jāyetha yavapalāpo yavakāraṇḍavoti.
segments.en: Suppose in a growing field of barley some bad barley appeared, just useless trash.

segments.pli: Tassa tādisaṃyeva mūlaṃ hoti, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ yavānaṃ;
segments.en: Its roots, stem, and leaves would look just the same as the healthy barley.

segments.pli: tādisaṃyeva nāḷaṃ hoti, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ yavānaṃ;
tādisaṃyeva pattaṃ hoti, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ yavānaṃ—

segments.en: That is, so long as the head doesn’t appear.

segments.pli: Yato ca khvassa sīsaṃ nibbattati, tamenaṃ evaṃ jānanti:
segments.en: But when the head appears, they know that it’s
bad barley, just useless trash.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ iti viditvā samūlaṃ uppāṭetvā bahiddhā yavakaraṇassa chaḍḍenti.
segments.en: When they realize this they pull it up by the roots and throw it outside the field.
Why is that?
So that it doesn’t spoil the good barley.

segments.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekaccassa puggalassa tādisaṃyeva hoti abhikkantaṃ paṭikkantaṃ ālokitaṃ vilokitaṃ samiñjitaṃ pasāritaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇaṃ, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ—
segments.en: In the same way, take a case where a certain person looks just the same as other good-natured mendicants when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and aside, when bending and extending the limbs, and when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes.
That is, so long as the mendicants don’t notice his offense.

segments.pli: Yato ca khvassa bhikkhū āpattiṃ passanti, tamenaṃ evaṃ jānanti:
segments.en: But when the mendicants notice the offense, they know that he’s
a corrupt ascetic, just useless trash.
When they realize this they send him away.
Why is that?
So that he doesn’t corrupt good-natured mendicants.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahato dhaññarāsissa phuṇamānassa tattha yāni tāni dhaññāni daḷhāni sāravantāni tāni ekamantaṃ puñjaṃ hoti, yāni pana tāni dhaññāni dubbalāni palāpāni tāni vāto ekamantaṃ apavahati.
segments.en: Suppose that a large heap of grain is being winnowed. The grains that are firm and substantial form a heap on one side. And the grains that are flimsy and insubstantial are blown over to the other side.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ sāmikā sammajjaniṃ gahetvā bhiyyoso mattāya apasammajjanti.
segments.en: Then the owners take a broom and sweep them even further away.
Why is that?
So that it doesn’t spoil the good grain.

segments.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekaccassa puggalassa tādisaṃyeva hoti abhikkantaṃ paṭikkantaṃ ālokitaṃ vilokitaṃ samiñjitaṃ pasāritaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇaṃ, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ—
segments.en: In the same way, take a case where a certain person looks just the same as other good-natured mendicants when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and aside, when bending and extending the limbs, and when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes.
That is, so long as the mendicants don’t notice his offense.

segments.pli: Yato ca khvassa bhikkhū āpattiṃ passanti, tamenaṃ evaṃ jānanti:
segments.en: But when the mendicants notice the offense, they know that he’s
a corrupt ascetic, just useless trash.
When they realize this they send him away.
Why is that?
So that he doesn’t corrupt good-natured mendicants.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso udapānapanāḷiyatthiko tiṇhaṃ kuṭhāriṃ ādāya vanaṃ paviseyya.
segments.en: Suppose a man needs an irrigation gutter for a well. He’d take a sharp axe and enter the wood,

segments.pli: So yaṃ yadeva rukkhaṃ kuṭhāripāsena ākoṭeyya tattha yāni tāni rukkhāni daḷhāni sāravantāni tāni kuṭhāripāsena ākoṭitāni kakkhaḷaṃ paṭinadanti;
segments.en: where he’d knock various trees with the axe. The trees that were firm and substantial made a cracking sound.

segments.pli: yāni pana tāni rukkhāni antopūtīni avassutāni kasambujātāni tāni kuṭhāripāsena ākoṭitāni daddaraṃ paṭinadanti.
segments.en: But the trees that were rotten inside, decomposing and decayed, made a thud.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ mūle chindati, mūle chinditvā agge chindati, agge chinditvā anto suvisodhitaṃ visodheti, anto suvisodhitaṃ visodhetvā udapānapanāḷiṃ yojeti.
segments.en: He’d cut down such a tree at the root, lop off the crown, and thoroughly clear out the insides. Then he’d use it as an irrigation gutter for the well.

segments.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekaccassa puggalassa tādisaṃyeva hoti abhikkantaṃ paṭikkantaṃ ālokitaṃ vilokitaṃ samiñjitaṃ pasāritaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇaṃ, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ—
segments.en: In the same way, take a case where a certain person looks just the same as other good-natured mendicants when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and aside, when bending and extending the limbs, and when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes.
That is, so long as the mendicants don’t notice his offense.

segments.pli: Yato ca khvassa bhikkhū āpattiṃ passanti, tamenaṃ evaṃ jānanti:
segments.en: But when the mendicants notice the offense, they know that he’s
a corrupt ascetic, just useless trash.
When they realize this they send him away.
Why is that?
So that he doesn’t corrupt good-natured mendicants.
By living together, know that
they’re irritable, with wicked desires,
offensive, stubborn, and contemptuous,
jealous, stingy, and devious.
They speak to people with a voice
so smooth, just like an ascetic.
But they act in secret, with their bad views
and their lack of regard for others.
You should recognize them for what they are:
a creep and liar.
Then having gathered in harmony,
you should expel them.
Throw out the trash!
Get rid of the rubbish!
And sweep away the scraps—
they’re not ascetics, they just think they are.
When you’ve thrown out those of wicked desires,
of bad behavior and alms-resort,
dwell in communion, ever mindful,
the pure with the pure.
Then in harmony, alert,
make an end of suffering.”

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā…

suttaplex.blurb: When a certain monk was admonished, he responded by attacking his reprovers. The Buddha tells the other monks to expel him, explaining that when such a monk lives hidden in the Saṅgha, his corruption can spread to the other monks.
